docs.abstract: Can bringing poems to the masses be an antidote to our toxic civic culture?
docs.snippet: Can bringing poems to the masses be an antidote to our toxic civic culture?
docs.lead_paragraph: One night in the summer of 2014, when she was teaching at the Middlebury Bread Loaf School of English in Vermont, Tracy K. Smith dreamed she was reading a poem printed on a wall. At first she thought it was by another poet, but as she reached the end, she realized it was her own. “If I wake up, I can get it,” she told herself.

headline.main: Tracy K. Smith, America’s Poet Laureate, Is a Woman With a Mission

docs.abstract: Mayonnaise from your fridge is the key to pulling this salad together quickly.
docs.snippet: Mayonnaise from your fridge is the key to pulling this salad together quickly.
docs.lead_paragraph: I have strong feelings about mayonnaise, the kinds of feelings that recently made me reconsider a friendship. Jessica Battilana has been my kindred cooking spirit for more than 10 years. Our careers as cooks and writers have taken us through the same Bay Area restaurants, bakeries, magazines and newspapers. We’ve explored year-round farmers’ markets and 12-course tasting menus. And through the fine-dining gantlet, we emerged as champions for no-nonsense, flavorful home cooking.

headline.main: A Green Goddess Dressing for When Speed Matters

docs.abstract: A previously unseen selection of the artist’s photographs, stored in a New York City apartment for over three decades, includes portraits of Keith Haring and Debbie Harry.
docs.snippet: A previously unseen selection of the artist’s photographs, stored in a New York City apartment for over three decades, includes portraits of Keith Haring and Debbie Harry.

headline.main: Rediscovered Photo Portraits by Andy Warhol

docs.slideshow_credits: Collection Anthony d’Offay, London, courtesy of Hedges Projects, Los Angeles.

docs.abstract: Life online can offer us a sense of belonging in any number of virtual villages. But the power to control those spaces isn’t very communal at all.
docs.snippet: Life online can offer us a sense of belonging in any number of virtual villages. But the power to control those spaces isn’t very communal at all.
docs.lead_paragraph: You can tell a lot about the cultural status of capitalism by how we refer to people who buy stuff. “Customer,” with its implicit deference — its suggestion that the buyer is always right — is now a relic of a bygone era. “Client” is formal and reserved for professional relationships. “Consumer,” with its air of piggish, Pac-Man voracity, is the slightly dehumanizing moniker most of us grew up with, but that was some time ago, before the rise of the brand as a cultic family. Now everyone who buys or uses or even just cares about a product or service has been collectively upgraded to something more ephemeral, almost spiritual, a loose association of souls brought together in one churchlike congregation: a “community.”

headline.main: What Good Is ‘Community’ When Someone Else Makes All the Rules?

docs.abstract: Do the pack-strap carry. But have a plan before the person becomes your cargo.
docs.snippet: Do the pack-strap carry. But have a plan before the person becomes your cargo.
docs.lead_paragraph: “You can be 4 feet 10 inches tall and 110 pounds soaking wet and still pick someone up,” says Sgt. First Class Nathan Lethgo, who oversees daily operations at the Army’s largest combat-medic training center, near San Antonio. During two deployments to Iraq and one to Afghanistan, Lethgo trained local soldiers and police officers in basic first aid, including hoisting the injured and unconscious. “First ask, ‘Does this person really need to be moved?’ ” Lethgo says.

headline.main: How to Carry Someone Who Is Unconscious
headline.print_headline: How to Carry Someone Who Is Unconscious

docs.abstract: A functional meal can still be vibrant.
docs.snippet: A functional meal can still be vibrant.
docs.lead_paragraph: We had really nice times, restaurants and I. There were the years when I worked for a food magazine with an expense account, and the years when my wife and I lived free of day care and diaper bills, so there are happy memories: the time I saw her weep, overcome by the flavor of a dish of strawberries; the time we spent an entire meal, rapt, watching servers glide toward tables, their dishes alighting in balletic unison.

headline.main: How to Make a Weeknight Grain Bowl That Is Actually Delicious

docs.abstract: On Montana’s Flathead Indian Reservation, basketball is about much more than winning.
docs.snippet: On Montana’s Flathead Indian Reservation, basketball is about much more than winning.
docs.lead_paragraph: Starting at noon on Feb. 23, the town of Arlee, Mont., evacuated. Most of its 600-odd residents drove 70 miles south through Missoula and then into the Bitterroot Valley, a river corridor full of subdivisions, trailers, exclusive private communities and ammunition stores. The crowd filtered into the gymnasium at Hamilton High School, wearing red shirts and pins bearing the faces of the Arlee Warriors basketball team, who that evening would be playing the Manhattan Christian Eagles.

headline.main: What the Arlee Warriors Were Playing For
headline.print_headline: What the Arlee Warriors Were Playing For

docs.abstract: Elwood Higginbotham was murdered by a mob in 1935. For his descendants, a new historical inquiry into his death offers a chance to confront the past.
docs.snippet: Elwood Higginbotham was murdered by a mob in 1935. For his descendants, a new historical inquiry into his death offers a chance to confront the past.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tina Washington can’t remember being told that white men lynched her granddaddy back in 1935. Somehow she’s always known. The crime echoed in her father’s character, in his watchfulness and distant love, in the yawning void left in place of memory. As a child, she tried to pry answers from her tight-lipped parents. “Where is my granddaddy?” she would ask. “I want to know my granddaddy.” Now, at 39, she asked different questions but mostly to herself. Would her father have gone to college if his daddy had lived? What did her granddaddy look like? What sparked his murder? Who were his people? She had no photos. Nothing.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Memorial for Peace and Justice (Montgomery, Ala)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mac writes: My wife, Judy, recently asked me if I would help her conceal the body if she committed a murder. I said no, which upset her. I later conceded that I would help her only if it was some sort of revenge killing. She says I should help her get away with murder under all circumstances. Who’s right?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Covering Up Your Spouse’s Crimes
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman
